ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Prof. Reuning-Scherer is great at explaining difficult concepts and making statistics interesting.
N/A

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I took the flipped version of this class, which gave me the opportunity to watch the class videos on my own time and use class time with Jonathan to work with data in the stats lab - this improved my understanding of the concepts and gave me a strong sense of familiarity with the stats software we were using. Enjoyed the flipped version of this class.
The assignments and work in class
Aside from the professor, I really enjoyed the flipped format, which allowed me to "learn by doing" more than my friends in the regular lecture format.

Jonathan! Without a doubt he is one of the most entertaining and responsive professors at FES. He is not only knowledgeable and an expert in the Statistical Sciences but he is highly approachable and makes boring concepts fun. Additionally, being in the flipped version of the class allowed me to spend more time in the classroom asking questions and learning by using minitab.

The flipped class is great because you get to do the "lectures" at home, and then have in-class time to focus on asking questions and working through examples and applications of what you learn during the lectures.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I understand that this is a "new" class, but it would be very helpful if the TAs/Jonathan could upload the videos earlier in the week.

Too much content and short period of time to cover and dominate the subjects covered during one semester. I didn't feel TAs were helpful to me. Most of the times they weren't prepare to advise about assignments. Couldn't answer my questions.
The selection of the TAs could improve.
Nothing. Perhaps the videos could be posted more in advance!
N/A

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Extremely effective and conducive to learning, especially with a subject like stats which requires hands-on practice and comfort with data.
Lab was necessary to put in practice what it was learned in the lectures (videos) prior classes.

For the flipped version of the class, I really enjoyed the time spent in the STATS lab just playing around with MINITAB and experimenting. It was perfectly complimentary to the online lectures and really helped synthesize learning.
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I had no quantitative background before this class - I gained hard skills and got familiar with Minitab, which will help me in my future research.
Its really useful for me specially to improve my research work.

This was a good down-and-dirty course in statistics. I hadn't taken a stats class since I was an undergraduate, and this was a good refresher course that went a bit beyond what I had learned in previous stat courses. I feel like I have a solid enough basis in statistics to understand general stat applications in research.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Answer above!
To help me improve my research skills. Understanding scientific papers.
I am just realizing how important statistical analysis is to every field!
I wanted to be able to understand basic stats well enough to conduct simple experimental design and analysis on my own.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes! I learned a lot and Jonathan is a great instructor.
No
Yes, absolutely.
Definitely. This was a valuable, well-taught course.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: As with all group projects, navigating my team-mates' schedules and carving out time to work on the project was a challenge.
Applying knowledge to practical exercises, knowing my classmates better, having fun during class.
Final project was a group project.
It helps to work through problems with other people, as it forces you to check over your work and make sure you thoroughly understand the concepts that are covered in the course.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Depends on the type of learner a person is, but I would highly recommend the flipped class - I know my peers in the non-flipped class found it difficult to do the HW and work with Minitab outside of class. I dont think the flipped folks had that problem.
Get the books and read before classes!
Definitely take it as long as Prof. Reuning-Scherer is teaching. Take the flipped format if it is offered in order to get more one-on-one learning time with the instructors.
Do it! It is so much better than the regular-style course. Flipped gives you way more direct access to the instructor and TAs and really helped me to grasp the material better.
